title: Logology (science)
text:
Logology is the study of all things related to <a href="science">science</a> and its <a href="scientist">practitioner</a>s—<a href="philosophy%20of%20science">philosophical</a>, biological, <a href="psychology%20of%20science">psychological</a>, <a href="sociology%20of%20science">societal</a>, <a href="history%20of%20science">historical</a>, <a href="politics">political</a>, <a href="research%20institute">institutional</a>, <a href="finance">financial</a>. The term "logology" is <a href="back-formation">back-formed</a> from the suffix "-logy", as in "geology", "anthropology", etc., in the sense of the "study of science".
The word "logology" provides grammatical variants not available with the earlier terms "science of science" and "sociology of science", such as "logologist", "logologize", "logological", and "logologically". The emerging field of <a href="metascience">metascience</a> is a subfield of logology.
Origins.
The early 20th century brought calls, initially from <a href="sociology">sociologists</a>, for the creation of a new, empirically-based <a href="science">science</a> that would study the <a href="science">scientific enterprise</a> itself. The early proposals were put forward with some hesitancy and tentativeness. The new <a href="Metascience%20%28research%29">meta-science</a> would be given a variety of names, including "science of knowledge", "science of science", "<a href="sociology%20of%20science">sociology of science</a>", and "logology".
<a href="Florian%20Znaniecki">Florian Znaniecki</a>, who is considered to be the founder of Polish academic sociology, and who in 1954 also served as the 44th president of the <a href="American%20Sociological%20Association">American Sociological Association</a>, opened a 1923 article:
[T]hough theoretical reflection on <a href="knowledge">knowledge</a>—which arose as early as <a href="Heraclitus">Heraclitus</a> and the <a href="Eleatics">Eleatics</a>—stretches... unbroken... through the history of human thought to the present day... we are now witnessing the creation of a new "science of knowledge" [author's emphasis] whose relation to the old inquiries may be compared with the relation of modern <a href="physics">physics</a> and <a href="chemistry">chemistry</a> to the '<a href="natural%20philosophy">natural philosophy</a>' that preceded them, or of contemporary <a href="sociology">sociology</a> to the '<a href="political%20philosophy">political philosophy</a>' of <a href="Classical%20antiquity">antiquity</a> and the <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>. [T]here is beginning to take shape a concept of a single, general theory of knowledge... permitting of empirical study... This theory... is coming to be distinguished clearly from <a href="epistemology">epistemology</a>, from normative <a href="logic">logic</a>, and from a strictly descriptive <a href="history%20of%20knowledge">history of knowledge</a>."
A dozen years later, Polish husband-and-wife sociologists <a href="Stanis%C5%82aw%20Ossowski">Stanisław Ossowski</a> and <a href="Maria%20Ossowska">Maria Ossowska</a> (the "Ossowscy") took up the same subject in an article on "The Science of Science" whose 1935 English-language version first introduced the term "science of science" to the world. The article postulated that the new discipline would subsume such earlier ones as <a href="epistemology">epistemology</a>, the <a href="philosophy%20of%20science">philosophy of science</a>, the <a href="psychology%20of%20science">psychology of science</a>, and the <a href="sociology%20of%20science">sociology of science</a>. The science of science would also concern itself with questions of a practical character such as social and state policy in relation to science, such as the organization of institutions of higher learning, of research institutes, and of scientific expeditions, and the protection of scientific workers, etc. It would concern itself as well with historical questions: the history of the conception of science, of the scientist, of the various disciplines, and of learning in general.
In their 1935 paper, the "Ossowscy" mentioned the German philosopher (1899–1953) who, in fragmentary 1931 remarks, had enumerated some possible types of research in the science of science and had proposed his own name for the new discipline: scientiology. The "Ossowscy" took issue with the name:
Those who wish to replace the expression 'science of science' by a one-word term [that] sound[s] international, in the belief that only after receiving such a name [will] a given group of [questions be] officially dubbed an autonomous discipline, [might] be reminded of the name 'mathesiology', proposed long ago for similar purposes [by the French mathematician and physicist <a href="Andr%C3%A9-Marie%20Amp%C3%A8re">André-Marie Ampère</a> (1775–1836)]."
Yet, before long, in Poland, the unwieldy three-word term "nauka o nauce", or science of science, was replaced by the more versatile one-word term "naukoznawstwo", or logology, and its natural variants: "naukoznawca" or logologist, "naukoznawczy" or logological, and "naukoznawczo" or logologically. And just after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, only 11 years after the "Ossowscy"s landmark 1935 paper, the year 1946 saw the founding of the <a href="Polish%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">Polish Academy of Sciences</a>' quarterly "Zagadnienia Naukoznawstwa" (Logology) –— long before similar journals in many other countries.
The new discipline also took root elsewhere—in English-speaking countries, without the benefit of a one-word name.
Science.
The term.
The word <a href="science">science</a>, from the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> "scientia" meaning <a href="knowledge">knowledge</a>, signifies somewhat different things in different languages. In <a href="English%20language">English</a>, science when unqualified, generally refers to the <a href="exact%20sciences">exact</a>, <a href="natural%20sciences">natural</a>, or <a href="hard%20sciences">hard sciences</a>. The corresponding terms in other languages, for example , <a href="%3AWissenschaft">German</a>, and , refer to a broader domain that includes not only the exact sciences (<a href="logic">logic</a> and <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>) and the natural sciences (<a href="physics">physics</a>, <a href="chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="biology">biology</a>, <a href="medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="Earth%20sciences">Earth sciences</a>, <a href="geography">geography</a>, <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a>, etc.) but also the <a href="engineering">engineering sciences</a>, <a href="social%20sciences">social sciences</a> (<a href="history">history</a>, <a href="geography">geography</a>, <a href="psychology">psychology</a>, <a href="physical%20anthropology">physical anthropology</a>, <a href="sociology">sociology</a>, <a href="political%20science">political science</a>, <a href="economics">economics</a>, <a href="international%20relations">international relations</a>, <a href="pedagogy">pedagogy</a>, etc.), and <a href="humanities">humanities</a> (<a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="history">history</a>, <a href="cultural%20anthropology">cultural anthropology</a>, <a href="linguistics">linguistics</a>, etc.).
<a href="University%20of%20Amsterdam">University of Amsterdam</a> humanities professor <a href="Rens%20Bod">Rens Bod</a> points out that science—defined as a set of <a href="Scientific%20method">methods</a> that describes and interprets <a href="observation">observed</a> or <a href="inference">inferred</a> <a href="phenomena">phenomena</a>, past or present, aimed at testing <a href="hypotheses">hypotheses</a> and building <a href="theories">theories</a>—applies to such humanities fields as <a href="philology">philology</a>, <a href="art%20history">art history</a>, <a href="musicology">musicology</a>, <a href="linguistics">linguistics</a>, <a href="archaeology">archaeology</a>, <a href="historiography">historiography</a>, and <a href="literary%20studies">literary studies</a>.
Bod gives a historic example of scientific <a href="Content%20analysis">textual analysis</a>. In 1440 the Italian philologist <a href="Lorenzo%20Valla">Lorenzo Valla</a> exposed the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> document "<a href="Donatio%20Constantini">Donatio Constantini</a>", or The Donation of Constantine – which was used by the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a> to legitimize its claim to lands in the <a href="Western%20Roman%20Empire">Western Roman Empire</a> – as a <a href="forgery">forgery</a>. Valla used historical, linguistic, and philological evidence, including <a href="counterfactual%20history">counterfactual reasoning</a>, to rebut the document. Valla found words and constructions in the document that could not have been used by anyone in the time of <a href="Emperor%20Constantine%20I">Emperor Constantine I</a>, at the beginning of the fourth century C.E. For example, the <a href="late%20Latin">late Latin</a> word "<a href="feudum">feudum</a>", meaning fief, referred to the <a href="feudal%20system">feudal system</a>, which would not come into existence until the <a href="Middle%20Ages">medieval</a> era, in the seventh century C.E. Valla's methods were those of science, and inspired the later scientifically-minded work of Dutch humanist <a href="Erasmus%20of%20Rotterdam">Erasmus of Rotterdam</a> (1466–1536), <a href="Leiden%20University">Leiden University</a> professor <a href="Joseph%20Justus%20Scaliger">Joseph Justus Scaliger</a> (1540–1609), and philosopher <a href="Baruch%20Spinoza">Baruch Spinoza</a> (1632–77). Here it is not the <a href="experimental%20method">experimental method</a> dominant in the <a href="exact%20sciences">exact</a> and <a href="natural%20sciences">natural sciences</a>, but the <a href="comparative%20method">comparative method</a> central to the <a href="humanities">humanities</a>, that reigns supreme.
Knowability.
Science's search for the <a href="truth">truth</a> about various aspects of <a href="reality">reality</a> entails the question of the very "knowability" of reality. Philosopher <a href="Thomas%20Nagel">Thomas Nagel</a> writes: "[In t]he pursuit of <a href="scientific%20knowledge">scientific knowledge</a> through the interaction between <a href="theory">theory</a> and <a href="observation">observation</a>... we test theories against their observational consequences, but we also question or reinterpret our observations in light of theory. (The choice between <a href="geocentric%20theory">geocentric</a> and <a href="heliocentric%20theory">heliocentric theories</a> at the time of the <a href="Copernican%20revolution">Copernican revolution</a> is a vivid example.) ...
How things seem is the starting point for all knowledge, and its development through further correction, extension, and elaboration is inevitably the result of more seemings—considered <a href="judgment">judgment</a>s about the plausibility and consequences of different theoretical <a href="hypothesis">hypotheses</a>. The only way to pursue the truth is to consider what seems true, after careful reflection of a kind appropriate to the subject matter, in light of all the relevant data, principles, and circumstances."
The question of knowability is approached from a different perspective by physicist-astronomer <a href="Marcelo%20Gleiser">Marcelo Gleiser</a>: "What we observe is not <a href="nature">nature</a> itself but nature as discerned through <a href="data">data</a> we collect from <a href="machine">machine</a>s. In consequence, the scientific <a href="worldview">worldview</a> depends on the <a href="information">information</a> we can acquire through our <a href="Scientific%20instrument">instrument</a>s. And given that our tools are limited, our view of the <a href="universe">world</a> is necessarily <a href="myopia">myopic</a>. We can see only so far into the nature of things, and our ever shifting scientific worldview reflects this fundamental limitation on how we perceive <a href="reality">reality</a>." Gleiser cites the condition of <a href="biology">biology</a> before and after the invention of the <a href="microscope">microscope</a> or <a href="DNA%20sequencing">gene sequencing</a>; of <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a> before and after the <a href="telescope">telescope</a>; of <a href="particle%20physics">particle physics</a> before and after <a href="collider">collider</a>s or fast electronics. "[T]he theories we build and the worldviews we construct change as our tools of exploration transform. This trend is the trademark of science."
Writes Gleiser: "There is nothing defeatist in understanding the limitations of the scientific approach to knowledge... What should change is a sense of scientific triumphalism—the belief that no question is beyond the reach of scientific discourse.
"There are clear unknowables in science—reasonable questions that, unless currently accepted laws of nature are violated, we cannot find answers to. One example is the <a href="multiverse">multiverse</a>: the conjecture that our <a href="universe">universe</a> is but one among a multitude of others, each potentially with a different set of <a href="Laws%20of%20science">laws of nature</a>. Other universes lie outside our causal horizon, meaning that we cannot receive or send signals to them. Any evidence for their existence would be circumstantial: for example, scars in the radiation permeating space because of a past collision with a neighboring universe."
Gleiser gives three further examples of unknowables, involving the origins of the <a href="universe">universe</a>; of <a href="life">life</a>; and of <a href="mind">mind</a>:
"Scientific accounts of the origin of the <a href="universe">universe</a> are incomplete because they must rely on a conceptual framework to even begin to work: <a href="energy%20conservation">energy conservation</a>, <a href="Theory%20of%20relativity">relativity</a>, <a href="quantum%20physics">quantum physics</a>, for instance. Why does the universe operate under these laws and not others?
"Similarly, unless we can prove that only one or very few <a href="biochemical%20pathway">biochemical pathway</a>s exist from nonlife to <a href="life">life</a>, we cannot know for sure how life originated on Earth.
"For <a href="consciousness">consciousness</a>, the problem is the jump from the <a href="material">material</a> to the <a href="Qualia">subjective</a>—for example, from firing <a href="neuron">neuron</a>s to the <a href="experience">experience</a> of <a href="pain">pain</a> or the <a href="color">color</a> red. Perhaps some kind of rudimentary consciousness could emerge in a sufficiently complex machine. But how could we tell? How do we establish—as opposed to conjecture—that something is conscious?" Paradoxically, writes Gleiser, it is through our consciousness that we make sense of the world, even if imperfectly. "Can we fully understand something of which we are a part?"
Among all the sciences (i.e., <a href="discipline%20%28academia%29">discipline</a>s of learning, writ large) there seems to exist an inverse relation between <a href="accuracy%20and%20precision">precision</a> and <a href="intuition">intuitiveness</a>. The most intuitive of the disciplines, aptly termed the "<a href="humanities">humanities</a>", relate to common human experience and, even at their most exact, are thrown back on the <a href="comparative%20method">comparative method</a>; less intuitive and more precise than the humanities are the <a href="social%20sciences">social sciences</a>; while, at the base of the inverted pyramid of the disciplines, physics (concerned with <a href="Hybrid%20word%23English%20examples">mattergy</a> – the <a href="matter">matter</a> and <a href="energy">energy</a> in the <a href="universe">universe</a>) is, at its deepest, the most precise discipline and at the same time utterly non-intuitive.
Facts and theories.
Theoretical physicist and mathematician <a href="Freeman%20Dyson">Freeman Dyson</a> explains that "[s]cience consists of <a href="fact">fact</a>s and <a href="theory">theories</a>":
"Facts are supposed to be true or false. They are discovered by observers or experimenters. A scientist who claims to have discovered a fact that turns out to be wrong is judged harshly...
"Theories have an entirely different status. They are free creations of the human mind, intended to describe our understanding of nature. Since our understanding is incomplete, theories are provisional. Theories are tools of understanding, and a tool does not need to be precisely true in order to be useful. Theories are supposed to be more-or-less true... A scientist who invents a theory that turns out to be wrong is judged leniently."
Dyson cites a psychologist's description of how theories are born: "We can't live in a state of perpetual doubt, so we make up the best story possible and we live as if the story were true." Dyson writes: "The inventor of a brilliant idea cannot tell whether it is right or wrong." The passionate pursuit of wrong theories is a normal part of the development of science. Dyson cites, after <a href="Mario%20Livio">Mario Livio</a>, five famous scientists who made major contributions to the understanding of nature but also believed firmly in a theory that proved wrong.
<a href="Charles%20Darwin">Charles Darwin</a> explained the <a href="evolution%20of%20life">evolution of life</a> with his <a href="theory%20of%20natural%20selection">theory of natural selection</a> of inherited variations, but he believed in a theory of blending inheritance that made the propagation of new variations impossible. He never read <a href="Gregor%20Mendel">Gregor Mendel</a>'s studies that showed that the <a href="laws%20of%20inheritance">laws of inheritance</a> would become simple when inheritance was considered as a <a href="randomness">random</a> process. Though Darwin in 1866 did the same experiment that Mendel had, Darwin did not get comparable results because he failed to appreciate the <a href="statistics">statistical</a> importance of using very large experimental <a href="sample%20%28statistics%29">sample</a>s. Eventually, <a href="Mendelian%20inheritance">Mendelian inheritance</a> by random variation would, no thanks to Darwin, provide the raw material for Darwinian selection to work on.
<a href="William%20Thomson%2C%201st%20Baron%20Kelvin">William Thomson (Lord Kelvin)</a> discovered basic laws of <a href="energy">energy</a> and <a href="heat">heat</a>, then used these laws to calculate an estimate of the <a href="age%20of%20the%20earth">age of the earth</a> that was too short by a factor of fifty. He based his calculation on the belief that the <a href="earth%27s%20mantle">earth's mantle</a> was solid and could transfer heat from the interior to the surface only by <a href="Thermal%20conduction">conduction</a>. It is now known that the mantle is partly fluid and transfers most of the heat by the far more efficient process of <a href="convection">convection</a>, which carries heat by a massive circulation of hot rock moving upward and cooler rock moving downward. Kelvin could see the eruptions of <a href="volcano">volcano</a>es bringing hot liquid from deep underground to the surface; but his skill in calculation blinded him to processes, such as <a href="volcanic%20eruptions">volcanic eruptions</a>, that could not be calculated.
<a href="Linus%20Pauling">Linus Pauling</a> discovered the chemical structure of <a href="protein">protein</a> and proposed a completely wrong structure for <a href="DNA">DNA</a>, which carries hereditary information from parent to offspring. Pauling guessed a wrong structure for DNA because he assumed that a pattern that worked for protein would also work for DNA. He overlooked the gross chemical differences between protein and DNA. <a href="Francis%20Crick">Francis Crick</a> and <a href="James%20Watson">James Watson</a> paid attention to the differences and found the correct structure for DNA that Pauling had missed a year earlier.
Astronomer <a href="Fred%20Hoyle">Fred Hoyle</a> discovered the process by which the heavier <a href="chemical%20element">element</a>s essential to <a href="life">life</a> are created by <a href="nuclear%20reaction">nuclear reaction</a>s in the cores of massive <a href="star">star</a>s. He then proposed a theory of the history of the universe known as <a href="steady-state%20cosmology">steady-state cosmology</a>, which has the <a href="universe">universe</a> existing forever without an initial <a href="Big%20Bang">Big Bang</a> (as Hoyle derisively dubbed it). He held his belief in the steady state long after observations proved that the Big Bang had happened.
<a href="Albert%20Einstein">Albert Einstein</a> discovered the theory of space, time, and gravitation known as <a href="general%20relativity">general relativity</a>, and then added a <a href="cosmological%20constant">cosmological constant</a>, later known as <a href="dark%20energy">dark energy</a>. Subsequently, Einstein withdrew his proposal of dark energy, believing it unnecessary. Long after his death, observations suggested that dark energy really exists, so that Einstein's addition to the theory may have been right; and his withdrawal, wrong.
To Mario Livio's five examples of scientists who blundered, Dyson adds a sixth: himself. Dyson had concluded, on theoretical principles, that what was to become known as the <a href="W-particle">W-particle</a>, a charged <a href="weak%20boson">weak boson</a>, could not exist. An experiment conducted at <a href="CERN">CERN</a>, in <a href="Geneva">Geneva</a>, later proved him wrong. "With hindsight I could see several reasons why my stability argument would not apply to W-particles. [They] are too massive and too short-lived to be a constituent of anything that resembles ordinary matter."
Truth.
<a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> <a href="history%20of%20science">historian of science</a> <a href="Naomi%20Oreskes">Naomi Oreskes</a> points out that the <a href="truth">truth</a> of scientific findings can never be assumed to be finally, absolutely settled. The history of science offers many examples of matters that scientists once thought to be settled and which have proven not to be, such as the concepts of <a href="Earth">Earth</a> being the center of the <a href="universe">universe</a>, the absolute nature of <a href="time">time</a> and <a href="space">space</a>, the stability of <a href="continent">continent</a>s, and the cause of <a href="infectious%20disease">infectious disease</a>.
Science, writes Oreskes, is not a fixed, immutable set of discoveries but "a "process" of learning and discovery [...]. Science can also be understood as an institution (or better, a set of institutions) that facilitates this work.
It is often asserted that scientific findings are true because scientists use "the <a href="scientific%20method">scientific method</a>". But, writes Oreskes, "we can never actually agree on what that method is. Some will say it is <a href="empiricism">empiricism</a>: <a href="observation">observation</a> and description of the world. Others will say it is the <a href="experimental%20method">experimental method</a>: the use of experience and experiment to test <a href="hypotheses">hypotheses</a>. (This is cast sometimes as the <a href="hypothetico-deductive%20method">hypothetico-deductive method</a>, in which the experiment must be framed as a deduction from theory, and sometimes as <a href="falsifiability">falsification</a>, where the point of observation and experiment is to refute theories, not to confirm them.) Recently a prominent scientist claimed the scientific method was to avoid fooling oneself into thinking something is true that is not, and vice versa."
In fact, writes Oreskes, the methods of science have varied between disciplines and across time. "Many scientific practices, particularly <a href="statistical%20significance">statistical tests of significance</a>, have been developed with the idea of avoiding wishful thinking and self-deception, but that hardly constitutes 'the scientific method.'"
Science, writes Oreskes, "is "not" simple, and neither is the <a href="natural%20environment">natural world</a>; therein lies the challenge of science communication. [...] Our efforts to understand and characterize the natural world are just that: efforts. Because we're human, we often fall flat."
"Scientific theories", according to Oreskes, "are not perfect replicas of <a href="reality">reality</a>, but we have good reason to believe that they capture significant elements of it."
Empiricism.
<a href="Steven%20Weinberg">Steven Weinberg</a>, 1979 <a href="Nobel%20Prize%20in%20physics">Nobel laureate in physics</a>, and a <a href="history%20of%20science">historian of science</a>, writes that the core goal of science has always been the same: "to explain the world"; and in reviewing earlier periods of scientific thought, he concludes that only since <a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a> has that goal been pursued more or less correctly. He decries the "intellectual snobbery" that <a href="Plato">Plato</a> and <a href="Aristotle">Aristotle</a> showed in their disdain for science's practical applications, and he holds <a href="Francis%20Bacon">Francis Bacon</a> and <a href="Ren%C3%A9%20Descartes">René Descartes</a> to have been the "most overrated" among the forerunners of modern science (they tried to prescribe rules for conducting science, which "never works").
Weinberg draws parallels between past and present science, as when a scientific theory is "fine-tuned" (adjusted) to make certain quantities equal, without any understanding of why they "should" be equal. Such adjusting vitiated the celestial models of Plato's followers, in which different spheres carrying the <a href="planet">planet</a>s and <a href="star">star</a>s were assumed, with no good reason, to rotate in exact unison. But, Weinberg writes, a similar fine-tuning also besets current efforts to understand the "<a href="dark%20energy">dark energy</a>" that is <a href="Accelerating%20universe">speeding up the expansion of the universe</a>.
Ancient science has been described as having gotten off to a good start, then faltered. The doctrine of <a href="atomism">atomism</a>, propounded by the <a href="pre-Socratic">pre-Socratic</a> philosophers <a href="Leucippus">Leucippus</a> and <a href="Democritus">Democritus</a>, was naturalistic, accounting for the workings of the world by impersonal processes, not by divine volitions. Nevertheless, these pre-Socratics come up short for Weinberg as proto-scientists, in that they apparently never tried to justify their speculations or to test them against evidence.
Weinberg believes that science faltered early on due to Plato's suggestion that scientific truth could be attained by reason alone, disregarding <a href="empirical%20observation">empirical observation</a>, and due to Aristotle's attempt to explain nature <a href="teleology">teleologically</a>—in terms of ends and purposes. Plato's ideal of attaining knowledge of the world by unaided intellect was "a false goal inspired by mathematics"—one that for centuries "stood in the way of progress that could be based only on careful analysis of careful observation." And it "never was fruitful" to ask, as Aristotle did, "what is the purpose of this or that physical phenomenon."
A scientific field in which the <a href="Ancient%20Greece">Greek</a> and <a href="Hellenistic">Hellenistic</a> world did make progress was astronomy. This was partly for practical reasons: the sky had long served as compass, clock, and calendar. Also, the regularity of the movements of heavenly bodies made them simpler to describe than earthly phenomena. But not "too" simple: though the sun, moon and "fixed stars" seemed regular in their celestial circuits, the "wandering stars"—the planets—were puzzling; they seemed to move at variable speeds, and even to reverse direction. Writes Weinberg: "Much of the story of the emergence of modern science deals with the effort, extending over two millennia, to explain the peculiar motions of the planets."
The challenge was to make sense of the apparently irregular wanderings of the planets on the assumption that all heavenly motion is actually circular and uniform in speed. Circular, because Plato held the <a href="circle">circle</a> to be the most perfect and symmetrical form; and therefore circular motion, at uniform speed, was most fitting for celestial bodies. Aristotle agreed with Plato. In Aristotle's <a href="cosmos">cosmos</a>, everything had a "natural" tendency to motion that fulfilled its inner potential. For the cosmos' sublunary part (the region below the moon), the natural tendency was to move in a straight line: downward, for earthen things (such as rocks) and water; upward, for air and fiery things (such as sparks). But in the <a href="Astronomical%20object">celestial</a> realm things were not composed of earth, water, air, or fire, but of a "fifth element", or "<a href="Aether%20%28classical%20element%29">quintessence</a>," which was perfect and eternal. And its natural motion was uniformly circular. The stars, the sun, the moon, and the planets were carried in their orbits by a complicated arrangement of crystalline spheres, all centered around an immobile earth.
The Platonic-Aristotelian conviction that celestial motions must be circular persisted stubbornly. It was fundamental to the astronomer <a href="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>'s system, which improved on Aristotle's in conforming to the astronomical data by allowing the planets to move in combinations of circles called "<a href="epicycle">epicycle</a>s".
It even survived the <a href="Copernican%20revolution">Copernican revolution</a>. Copernicus was conservative in his Platonic reverence for the circle as the heavenly pattern. According to Weinberg, Copernicus was motivated to dethrone the earth in favor of the sun as the immobile center of the cosmos largely by aesthetic considerations: he objected to the fact that Ptolemy, though faithful to Plato's requirement that heavenly motion be circular, had departed from Plato's other requirement that it be of uniform speed. By putting the sun at the center—actually, somewhat off-center—Copernicus sought to honor circularity while restoring uniformity. But to make his system fit the observations as well as Ptolemy's system, Copernicus had to introduce still more epicycles. That was a mistake that, writes Weinberg, illustrates a recurrent theme in the history of science: "A simple and beautiful theory that agrees pretty well with observation is often closer to the truth than a complicated ugly theory that agrees better with observation."
The planets, however, do not move in perfect circles but in <a href="ellipse">ellipse</a>s. It was <a href="Johannes%20Kepler">Johannes Kepler</a>, about a century after Copernicus, who reluctantly (for he too had Platonic affinities) realized this. Thanks to his examination of the meticulous observations compiled by astronomer <a href="Tycho%20Brahe">Tycho Brahe</a>, Kepler "was the first to understand the nature of the departures from uniform circular motion that had puzzled astronomers since the time of Plato."
The replacement of circles by supposedly ugly ellipses overthrew Plato's notion of <a href="Perfection%23Aesthetics">perfection</a> as the celestial explanatory principle. It also destroyed Aristotle's model of the planets carried in their orbits by crystalline spheres; writes Weinberg, "there is no solid body whose rotation can produce an ellipse." Even if a planet were attached to an ellipsoid crystal, that crystal's rotation would still trace a circle. And if the planets were pursuing their elliptical motion through empty space, then what was holding them in their orbits?
Science had reached the threshold of explaining the world not <a href="geometry">geometrically</a>, according to shape, but dynamically, according to <a href="force">force</a>. It was <a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a> who finally crossed that threshold. He was the first to formulate, in his "<a href="Newton%27s%20laws%20of%20motion">laws of motion</a>", the concept of force. He demonstrated that Kepler's ellipses were the very orbits the planets would take if they were attracted toward the sun by a force that decreased as the square of the planet's distance from the sun. And by comparing the moon's motion in its orbit around the earth to the motion of, perhaps, an apple as it falls to the ground, Newton deduced that the forces governing them were quantitatively the same. "This," writes Weinberg, "was the climactic step in the unification of the celestial and terrestrial in science."
By formulating a unified explanation of the behavior of planets, comets, moons, tides, and apples, writes Weinberg, Newton "provided an irresistible model for what a <a href="physical%20theory">physical theory</a> should be"—a model that fit no preexisting <a href="metaphysics">metaphysical</a> criterion. In contrast to Aristotle, who claimed to explain the falling of a rock by appeal to its inner striving, Newton was unconcerned with finding a deeper cause for <a href="gravity">gravity</a>. He declared in a postscript to the second, 1713 edition of his "<a href="Philosophi%C3%A6%20Naturalis%20Principia%20Mathematica">Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica</a>": "I have not as yet been able to deduce from phenomena the reason for these properties of gravity, and I do not feign hypotheses. It is enough that gravity really exists and acts according to the laws that we have set forth." What mattered were his mathematically stated principles describing this force, and their ability to account for a vast range of phenomena.
About two centuries later, in 1915, a deeper explanation for Newton's law of gravitation was found in <a href="Albert%20Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>'s <a href="general%20theory%20of%20relativity">general theory of relativity</a>: gravity could be explained as a manifestation of the curvature in <a href="spacetime">spacetime</a> resulting from the presence of <a href="matter">matter</a> and <a href="energy">energy</a>. Successful theories like Newton's, writes Weinberg, may work for reasons that their creators do not understand—reasons that deeper theories will later reveal. Scientific progress is not a matter of building theories on a foundation of <a href="reason">reason</a>, but of unifying a greater range of <a href="phenomenon">phenomena</a> under simpler and more general principles.
Artificial intelligence.
The term "<a href="artificial%20intelligence">artificial intelligence</a>" (AI) was coined in 1955 by <a href="John%20McCarthy%20%28computer%20scientist%29">John McCarthy</a> when he and other <a href="computer%20scientist">computer scientist</a>s were planning a workshop and did not want to invite <a href="Norbert%20Wiener">Norbert Wiener</a>, the brilliant, pugnacious, and increasingly philosophical (rather than practical) author on <a href="feedback%20mechanism">feedback mechanism</a>s who had coined the term "<a href="cybernetics">cybernetics</a>". The new term "artificial intelligence", writes <a href="Kenneth%20Cukier">Kenneth Cukier</a>, "set in motion decades of semantic squabbles ('Can machines think?') and fueled anxieties over malicious robots... If McCarthy... had chosen a blander phrase—say, 'automation studies'—the concept might not have appealed as much to <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> [movie] producers and [to] journalists..."
As machines have become increasingly capable, specific tasks considered to require "intelligence", such as <a href="optical%20character%20recognition">optical character recognition</a>, have often been removed from the definition of AI, a phenomenon known as the "<a href="AI%20effect">AI effect</a>". It has been quipped that "AI is whatever hasn't been done yet."
Since 1950, when <a href="Alan%20Turing">Alan Turing</a> proposed what has come to be called the "<a href="Turing%20test">Turing test</a>," there has been speculation whether machines such as computers can possess intelligence; and, if so, <a href="Technological%20singularity">whether intelligent machines could become a threat to human intellectual and scientific ascendancy</a>—or even an existential threat to humanity. <a href="John%20Searle">John Searle</a> points out common confusion about the correct interpretation of computation and information technology. "For example, one routinely reads that in exactly the same sense in which <a href="Garry%20Kasparov">Garry Kasparov</a>… beat <a href="Anatoly%20Karpov">Anatoly Karpov</a> in <a href="chess">chess</a>, the computer called <a href="Deep%20Blue%20%28chess%20computer%29">Deep Blue</a> played and beat Kasparov... [T]his claim is [obviously] suspect. In order for Kasparov to play and win, he has to be conscious that he is playing chess, and conscious of a thousand other things... Deep Blue is conscious of none of these things because it is not conscious of anything at all. Why is <a href="consciousness">consciousness</a> so important? You cannot literally play chess or do much of anything else cognitive if you are totally disassociated from consciousness."
Searle explains that, "in the literal, real, observer-independent sense in which humans compute, mechanical computers do not compute. They go through a set of transitions in electronic states that we can interpret computationally. The transitions in those electronic states are absolute or observer-independent, but "the computation is observer-relative". The transitions in physical states are just electrical sequences unless some conscious agent can give them a computational interpretation... There is no psychological reality at all to what is happening in the [computer]."
"[A] digital computer", writes Searle, "is a syntactical machine. It manipulates symbols and does nothing else. For this reason, the project of creating human intelligence by designing a computer program that will pass the <a href="Turing%20Test">Turing Test</a>... is doomed from the start. The appropriately programmed computer has a <a href="syntax">syntax</a> [rules for constructing or transforming the symbols and words of a language] but no <a href="semantics">semantics</a> [comprehension of meaning]... Minds, on the other hand, have mental or semantic content."
Like Searle, <a href="Christof%20Koch">Christof Koch</a>, chief scientist and president of the <a href="Allen%20Institute%20for%20Brain%20Science">Allen Institute for Brain Science</a>, in <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>, is doubtful about the possibility of "intelligent" machines attaining <a href="consciousness">consciousness</a>, because "[e]ven the most sophisticated <a href="brain%20simulation">brain simulation</a>s are unlikely to produce conscious <a href="feelings">feelings</a>." According to Koch, "Whether machines can become <a href="sentience">sentient</a> [is important] for <a href="ethics">ethical</a> reasons. If computers experience life through their own senses, they cease to be purely a means to an end determined by their usefulness to... humans. Per GNW [the <a href="Global%20Workspace%20Theory%23Global%20neuronal%20workspace">Global Neuronal Workspace</a> theory], they turn from mere objects into subjects... with a <a href="point%20of%20view%20%28philosophy%29">point of view</a>... Once computers' <a href="cognitive%20abilities">cognitive abilities</a> rival those of humanity, their impulse to push for legal and political <a href="rights">rights</a> will become irresistible – the right not to be deleted, not to have their memories wiped clean, not to suffer <a href="pain">pain</a> and degradation. The alternative, embodied by IIT [Integrated Information Theory], is that computers will remain only supersophisticated machinery, ghostlike empty shells, devoid of what we value most: the feeling of life itself."
Professor of psychology and neural science <a href="Gary%20Marcus">Gary Marcus</a> points out a so far insuperable stumbling block to artificial intelligence: an incapacity for reliable <a href="disambiguation">disambiguation</a>. "[V]irtually every sentence [that people generate] is <a href="ambiguity">ambiguous</a>, often in multiple ways. Our brain is so good at comprehending <a href="language">language</a> that we do not usually notice." A prominent example is known as the "pronoun disambiguation problem" ("PDP"): a machine has no way of determining to whom or what a <a href="pronoun">pronoun</a> in a sentence—such as "he", "she" or "it"—refers.
<a href="Computer%20science">Computer scientist</a> <a href="Pedro%20Domingos">Pedro Domingos</a> writes: "AIs are like <a href="autistic%20savant">autistic savant</a>s and will remain so for the foreseeable future... AIs lack <a href="common%20sense">common sense</a> and can easily make errors that a human never would... They are also liable to take our instructions too literally, giving us precisely what we asked for instead of what we actually wanted.
<a href="Kai-Fu%20Lee">Kai-Fu Lee</a>, a <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>-based <a href="venture%20capital">venture capital</a>ist, <a href="artificial%20intelligence">artificial-intelligence</a> (AI) expert with a <a href="Ph.D.">Ph.D.</a> in <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a> from <a href="Carnegie%20Mellon%20University">Carnegie Mellon University</a>, and author of the 2018 book, "AI Superpowers: China, Silicon Valley, and the New World Order", emphasized in a 2018 <a href="PBS">PBS</a> "<a href="Amanpour">Amanpour</a>" interview with <a href="Hari%20Sreenivasan">Hari Sreenivasan</a> that <a href="AI">AI</a>, with all its capabilities, will never be capable of <a href="creativity">creativity</a> or <a href="empathy">empathy</a>. Paul Scharre writes in "<a href="Foreign%20Affairs">Foreign Affairs</a>" that "Today's AI technologies are powerful but unreliable." <a href="George%20Dyson%20%28science%20historian%29">George Dyson</a>, historian of computing, writes (in what might be called "Dyson's Law") that "Any system simple enough to be understandable will not be complicated enough to behave intelligently, while any system complicated enough to behave intelligently will be too complicated to understand." Computer scientist <a href="Alex%20Pentland">Alex Pentland</a> writes: "Current <a href="machine%20learning">AI machine-learning</a> <a href="algorithm">algorithm</a>s are, at their core, dead simple stupid. They work, but they work by brute force."
"Artificial intelligence" is synonymous with "<a href="machine%20intelligence">machine intelligence</a>." The more perfectly adapted an AI program is to a given task, the less applicable it will be to other specific tasks. An abstracted, AI <a href="general%20intelligence">general intelligence</a> is a remote prospect, if feasible at all. <a href="Melanie%20Mitchell">Melanie Mitchell</a> notes that an AI program called <a href="AlphaGo">AlphaGo</a> bested one of the world's best <a href="Go%20%28game%29">Go</a> players, but that its "intelligence" is nontransferable: it cannot "think" about anything except Go. Mitchell writes: "We humans tend to overestimate AI advances and underestimate the complexity of our own intelligence." Writes Paul Taylor: "Perhaps there is a limit to what a computer can do without knowing that it is manipulating imperfect representations of an external reality."
Humankind may not be able to outsource, to machines, its creative efforts in the sciences, technology, and culture.
Uncertainty.
A central concern for science and scholarship is the <a href="Reliability%20%28statistics%29">reliability</a> and <a href="reproducibility">reproducibility</a> of their findings. Of all fields of study, none is capable of such precision as <a href="physics">physics</a>. But even there the results of studies, observations, and <a href="experiments">experiments</a> cannot be considered absolutely certain and must be treated <a href="probability">probabilistically</a>; hence, <a href="statistics">statistically</a>.
In 1925 British geneticist and statistician <a href="Ronald%20Fisher">Ronald Fisher</a> published "Statistical Methods for Research Workers", which established him as the father of modern statistics. He proposed a statistical test that summarized the compatibility of data with a given proposed model and produced a "<a href="p%20value">"p" value</a>". He counselled pursuing results with "p" values below 0.05 and not wasting time on results above that. Thus arose the idea that a "p" value less than 0.05 constitutes "<a href="statistical%20significance">statistical significance</a>" – a mathematical definition of "significant" results.
The use of "p" values, ever since, to determine the statistical significance of experimental results has contributed to an illusion of <a href="certainty">certainty</a> and to <a href="reproducibility">reproducibility crises</a> in many <a href="science">scientific fields</a>, especially in <a href="experimental%20economics">experimental economics</a>, <a href="biomedical%20research">biomedical research</a>, and <a href="psychology">psychology</a>.
Every statistical model relies on a set of assumptions about how data are collected and analyzed and about how researchers decide to present their results. These results almost always center on <a href="null%20hypothesis">null-hypothesis</a> significance testing, which produces a "p" value. Such testing does not address the truth head-on but obliquely: significance testing is meant to indicate only whether a given line of research is worth pursuing further. It does not say how likely the hypothesis is to be true, but instead addresses an alternative question: if the hypothesis were false, how unlikely would the data be? The importance of "statistical significance", reflected in the "p" value, can be exaggerated or overemphasized – something that readily occurs with small samples. That has caused <a href="replication%20crisis">replication crises</a>.
Some scientists have advocated "redefining statistical significance", shifting its threshold from 0.05 to 0.005 for claims of new discoveries. Others say such redefining does no good because the real problem is the very existence of a threshold.
Some scientists prefer to use <a href="Bayesian%20methods">Bayesian methods</a>, a more direct statistical approach which takes initial beliefs, adds in new evidence, and updates the beliefs. Another alternative procedure is to use the <a href="surprisal">surprisal</a>, a mathematical quantity that adjust "p" values to produce bits – as in computer bits – of information; in that perspective, 0.05 is a weak standard.
When Ronald Fisher embraced the concept of "significance" in the early 20th century, it meant "signifying" but not "important". Statistical "significance" has, since, acquired am excessive connotation of confidence in the validity of the experimental results. Statistician Andrew Gelman says, "The original sin is people wanting <a href="certainty">certainty</a> when it's not appropriate." "Ultimately", writes Lydia Denworth, "a successful theory is one that stands up repeatedly to decades of scrutiny."
Increasingly, attention is being given to the principles of <a href="open%20science">open science</a>, such as publishing more detailed research protocols and requiring authors to follow prespecified analysis plans and to report when they deviate from them.

Reproducibility.
A fundamental feature of the scientific enterprise is <a href="reproducibility">reproducibility</a> of results. "For decades", writes Shannon Palus, "it has been... an <a href="open%20secret">open secret</a> that a [considerable part] of the literature in some fields is plain wrong." This effectively sabotages the scientific enterprise and costs the world many billions of dollars annually in wasted resources. Militating against reproducibility is scientists' reluctance to share techniques, for fear of forfeiting one's advantage to other scientists. Also, <a href="scientific%20journal">scientific journal</a>s and <a href="tenure">tenure</a> committees tend to prize impressive new results rather than gradual advances that systematically build on existing literature. Scientists who quietly fact-check others' work or spend extra time ensuring that their own <a href="Protocol%20%28science%29">protocol</a>s are easy for other researchers to understand, gain little for themselves.
With a view to improving reproducibility of scientific results, it has been suggested that research-funding agencies finance only projects that include a plan for making their work <a href="open%20research">transparent</a>. In 2016 the U.S. <a href="National%20Institutes%20of%20Health">National Institutes of Health</a> introduced new application instructions and review questions to encourage scientists to improve reproducibility. The NIH requests more information on how the study builds on previous work, and a list of variables that could affect the study, such as the sex of animal subjects—a previously overlooked factor that led many studies to describe phenomena found in male animals as universal.
Likewise, the questions that a funder can ask in advance could be asked by journals and reviewers. One solution is "registered reports", a preregistration of studies whereby a scientist submits, for publication, research analysis and design plans before actually doing the study. <a href="Peer%20review">Peer review</a>ers then evaluate the <a href="methodology">methodology</a>, and the journal promises to print the results, no matter what they are. In order to prevent over-reliance on preregistered studies—which could encourage safer, less venturesome research, thus over-correcting the problem—the preregistered-studies model could be operated in tandem with the traditional results-focused model, which may sometimes be more friendly to <a href="serendipity">serendipitous</a> discoveries.
The "replication crisis" is compounded by a finding, published in a study summarized in 2021 by historian of science <a href="Naomi%20Oreskes">Naomi Oreskes</a>, that nonreplicable studies are cited oftener than replicable ones: in other words, that bad science seems to get more attention than good science. If a substantial proportion of science in unreplicable, it will not provide a valid basis for decision-making and may delay the use of science for developing new medicines and technologies. It may also undermine the public's trust, making it harder to get people <a href="vaccine">vaccinated</a> or act against <a href="climate%20change">climate change</a>.
The study tracked papers – in psychology journals, economics journals, and in "<a href="Science%20%28journal%29">Science</a>" and "<a href="Nature%20%28journal%29">Nature</a>" – with documented failures of replication. The unreplicable papers were cited more than average, even after news of their unreplicability had been published.
"These results," writes Oreskes, "parallel those of a 2018 study. An analysis of 126,000 rumor cascades on <a href="Twitter">Twitter</a> showed that false news spread faster and reached more people than verified true claims. [I]t was people, not [ro]bots, who were responsible for the disproportionate spread of falsehoods online."

A 2016 "<a href="Scientific%20American">Scientific American</a>" report highlights the role of "rediscovery" in science. <a href="Indiana%20University%20Bloomington">Indiana University Bloomington</a> researchers combed through 22 million scientific papers published over the previous century and found dozens of "Sleeping Beauties"—studies that lay dormant for years before getting noticed. The top finds, which languished longest and later received the most intense attention from scientists, came from the fields of chemistry, physics, and statistics. The dormant findings were wakened by scientists from other disciplines, such as <a href="medicine">medicine</a>, in search of fresh insights, and by the ability to test once-theoretical postulations. Multiple discovery.
Historians and sociologists have remarked the occurrence, in <a href="science">science</a>, of "<a href="multiple%20discovery">multiple independent discovery</a>". Sociologist <a href="Robert%20K.%20Merton">Robert K. Merton</a> defined such "multiples" as instances in which similar <a href="Discovery%20%28observation%29">discoveries</a> are made by scientists working independently of each other. "Sometimes the discoveries are simultaneous or almost so; sometimes a scientist will make a new discovery which, unknown to him, somebody else has made years before." Commonly cited examples of multiple independent discovery are the 17th-century independent formulation of <a href="calculus">calculus</a> by <a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a>, <a href="Gottfried%20Wilhelm%20Leibniz">Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz</a>, and others; the 18th-century independent discovery of <a href="oxygen">oxygen</a> by <a href="Carl%20Wilhelm%20Scheele">Carl Wilhelm Scheele</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Priestley">Joseph Priestley</a>, <a href="Antoine%20Lavoisier">Antoine Lavoisier</a>, and others; and the 19th-century independent formulation of the <a href="theory%20of%20evolution">theory of evolution</a> of <a href="species">species</a> by <a href="Charles%20Darwin">Charles Darwin</a> and <a href="Alfred%20Russel%20Wallace">Alfred Russel Wallace</a>.
Merton contrasted a "multiple" with a "singleton" — a discovery that has been made uniquely by a single scientist or group of scientists working together. He believed that it is multiple discoveries, rather than unique ones, that represent the "common" pattern in science.
Multiple discoveries in the history of science provide evidence for <a href="evolution">evolution</a>ary models of science and technology, such as <a href="memetics">memetics</a> (the study of self-replicating units of culture), <a href="evolutionary%20epistemology">evolutionary epistemology</a> (which applies the concepts of <a href="biological%20evolution">biological evolution</a> to study of the growth of human knowledge), and <a href="cultural%20selection%20theory">cultural selection theory</a> (which studies sociological and cultural evolution in a Darwinian manner). A <a href="recombinant%20DNA">recombinant-DNA</a>-inspired "<a href="paradigm">paradigm</a> of paradigms", describing a mechanism of "recombinant conceptualization", predicates that a new <a href="concept">concept</a> arises through the crossing of pre-existing concepts and <a href="fact">fact</a>s. This is what is meant when one says that a scientist, scholar, or artist has been "influenced by" another — <a href="etymology">etymologically</a>, that a concept of the latter's has "flowed into" the mind of the former.
The phenomenon of multiple independent discoveries and inventions can be viewed as a consequence of <a href="Boles%C5%82aw%20Prus">Bolesław Prus</a>' three laws of gradualness, dependence, and combination (see "<a href="Logology%20%28science%20of%20science%29%23Discoveries%20and%20inventions">Discoveries and inventions</a>", above). The first two laws may, in turn, be seen as corollaries to the third law, since the laws of gradualness and dependence imply the impossibility of certain scientific or technological advances pending the availability of certain theories, facts, or technologies that must be combined to produce a given scientific or technological advance.
Technology.
<a href="Technology">Technology</a> – the application of discoveries to practical matters – showed a remarkable acceleration in what economist <a href="Robert%20J.%20Gordon">Robert J. Gordon</a> has identified as "the special century" that spanned the period up to 1970. By then, he writes, all the key technologies of modern life were in place: <a href="sanitation">sanitation</a>, <a href="electricity">electricity</a>, <a href="mechanized%20agriculture">mechanized agriculture</a>, <a href="highway">highway</a>s, <a href="air%20travel">air travel</a>, <a href="telecommunications">telecommunications</a>, and the like. The one signature technology of the 21st century has been the <a href="iPhone">iPhone</a>. Meanwhile, a long list of much-publicized potential major technologies remain in the <a href="prototype">prototype</a> phase, including <a href="self-driving%20cars">self-driving cars</a>, <a href="flying%20cars">flying cars</a>, <a href="augmented%20reality">augmented-reality glasses</a>, <a href="gene%20therapy">gene therapy</a>, and <a href="nuclear%20fusion">nuclear fusion</a>. An urgent goal for the 21st century, writes Gordon, is to undo some of the consequences of the last great technology boom by developing affordable <a href="Zero%20emission">zero- and negative-emissions technologies</a>.

Habitus.

Nonconformance.
A practical question concerns the traits that enable some individuals to achieve extraordinary results in their fields of work—and how such <a href="creativity">creativity</a> can be fostered. <a href="Melissa%20Schilling">Melissa Schilling</a>, a student of <a href="innovation">innovation</a> strategy, has identified some traits shared by eight major innovators in <a href="natural%20science">natural science</a> or <a href="technology">technology</a>: <a href="Benjamin%20Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> (1706–90), <a href="Thomas%20Edison">Thomas Edison</a> (1847–1931), <a href="Nikola%20Tesla">Nikola Tesla</a> (1856–1943), <a href="Maria%20Sk%C5%82odowska%20Curie">Maria Skłodowska Curie</a> (1867–1934), <a href="Dean%20Kamen">Dean Kamen</a> (born 1951), <a href="Steve%20Jobs">Steve Jobs</a> (1955–2011), <a href="Albert%20Einstein">Albert Einstein</a> (1879–1955), and <a href="Elon%20Musk">Elon Musk</a> (born 1971).
Schilling chose innovators in natural science and technology rather than in other fields because she found much more consensus about important contributions to natural science and technology than, for example, to art or music. She further limited the set to individuals associated with "multiple" innovations. "When an individual is associated with only a single major invention, it is much harder to know whether the invention was caused by the inventor's personal characteristics or by simply being at the right place at the right time."
The eight individuals were all extremely intelligent, but "that is not enough to make someone a serial breakthrough innovator." Nearly all these innovators showed very high levels of <a href="Emotional%20detachment">social detachment</a>, or separateness (a notable exception being Benjamin Franklin). "Their isolation meant that they were less exposed to dominant ideas and norms, and their sense of not belonging meant that even when exposed to dominant ideas and norms, they were often less inclined to adopt them." From an early age, they had all shown extreme faith in their ability to overcome obstacles—what <a href="psychology">psychology</a> calls "<a href="self-efficacy">self-efficacy</a>".
"Most [of them, writes Schilling] were driven by <a href="Ideal%20%28ethics%29">idealism</a>, a superordinate goal that was more important than their own comfort, reputation, or families. Nikola Tesla wanted to free mankind from labor through unlimited free <a href="energy">energy</a> and to achieve international <a href="peace">peace</a> through global <a href="communication">communication</a>. Elon Musk wants to solve the world's energy problems and colonize <a href="Mars">Mars</a>. Benjamin Franklin was seeking greater social harmony and productivity through the ideals of <a href="egalitarianism">egalitarianism</a>, <a href="toleration">tolerance</a>, industriousness, temperance, and charity. Marie Curie had been inspired by <a href="Positivism%20in%20Poland">Polish Positivism</a>'s argument that <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, which was under Tsarist Russian rule, could be preserved only through the pursuit of education and technological advance by all Poles—"including women"."
Most of the innovators also worked hard and tirelessly because they found work extremely rewarding. Some had an extremely high need for achievement. Many also appeared to find work <a href="autotelic">autotelic</a>—rewarding for its own sake. A surprisingly large portion of the breakthrough innovators have been <a href="autodidact">autodidact</a>s—self-taught persons—and excelled much more outside the classroom than inside.
"Almost all breakthrough innovation," writes Schilling, "starts with an unusual idea or with beliefs that break with <a href="conventional%20wisdom">conventional wisdom</a>... However, creative ideas alone are almost never enough. Many people have creative ideas, even brilliant ones. But usually we lack the time, knowledge, money, or motivation to act on those ideas." It is generally hard to get others' help in implementing original ideas because the ideas are often initially hard for others to understand and value. Thus each of Schilling's breakthrough innovators showed "extraordinary" effort and persistence. Even so, writes Schilling, "being at the right place at the right time still matter[ed]."
Lichenology.
When Swiss botanist <a href="Simon%20Schwendener">Simon Schwendener</a> discovered in the 1860s that <a href="lichen">lichen</a>s were a <a href="symbiosis">symbiotic</a> partnership between a <a href="fungus">fungus</a> and an <a href="alga">alga</a>, his finding at first met with resistance from the scientific community. After his discovery that the fungus—which cannot make its own food—provides the lichen's structure, while the alga's contribution is its <a href="photosynthesis">photosynthetic</a> production of food, it was found that in some lichens a <a href="cyanobacterium">cyanobacterium</a> provides the food—and a handful of lichen species contain "both" an alga and a cyanobacterium, along with the fungus.
A self-taught naturalist, <a href="Trevor%20Goward">Trevor Goward</a>, has helped create a <a href="paradigm%20shift">paradigm shift</a> in the study of lichens and perhaps of all life-forms by doing something that people did in pre-scientific times: going out into nature and closely observing. His essays about lichens were largely ignored by most researchers because Goward has no scientific degrees and because some of his radical ideas are not supported by rigorous data.
When Goward told <a href="Toby%20Spribille">Toby Spribille</a>, who at the time lacked a high-school education, about some of his lichenological ideas, Goward recalls, "He said I was delusional." Ultimately Spribille passed a high-school equivalency examination, obtained a Ph.D. in lichenology at the <a href="University%20of%20Graz">University of Graz</a> in Austria, and became an assistant professor of the ecology and evolution of symbiosis at the <a href="University%20of%20Alberta">University of Alberta</a>. In July 2016 Spribille and his co-authors published a ground-breaking paper in "<a href="Science%20%28journal%29">Science</a>" revealing that many lichens contain a second fungus.
Spribille credits Goward with having "a huge influence on my thinking. [His essays] gave me license to think about lichens in [an unorthodox way] and freed me to see the patterns I worked out in "<a href="Bryoria">Bryoria</a>" with my co-authors." Even so, "one of the most difficult things was allowing myself to have an open mind to the idea that 150 years of literature may have entirely missed the theoretical possibility that there would be more than one fungal partner in the lichen symbiosis." Spribille says that academia's emphasis on the canon of what others have established as important is inherently limiting.
Leadership.
Contrary to previous studies indicating that higher <a href="intelligence">intelligence</a> makes for better <a href="leadership">leaders</a> in various fields of endeavor, later research suggests that, at a certain point, a higher <a href="IQ">IQ</a> can be viewed as harmful. Decades ago, psychologist <a href="Dean%20Simonton">Dean Simonton</a> suggested that brilliant leaders' words may go over people's heads, their solutions could be more complicated to implement, and followers might find it harder to relate to them. At last, in the July 2017 "<a href="Journal%20of%20Applied%20Psychology">Journal of Applied Psychology</a>", he and two colleagues published the results of actual tests of the hypothesis.
Studied were 379 men and women business leaders in 30 countries, including the fields of banking, retail, and technology. The managers took IQ tests—an imperfect but robust predictor of performance in many areas—and each was rated on leadership style and effectiveness by an average of 8 co-workers. IQ correlated positively with ratings of leadership effectiveness, <a href="strategy">strategy</a> formation, <a href="Foresight%20%28psychology%29">vision</a>, and several other characteristics—up to a point. The ratings peaked at an IQ of about 120, which is higher than some 80% of office workers. Beyond that, the ratings declined. The researchers suggested that the ideal IQ could be higher or lower in various fields, depending on whether technical or <a href="social%20skills">social skills</a> are more valued in a given work culture.
Psychologist Paul Sackett, not involved in the research, comments: "To me, the right interpretation of the work would be that it highlights a need to understand what high-IQ leaders do that leads to lower perceptions by followers. The wrong interpretation would be,'Don't hire high-IQ leaders.'" The study's <a href="lead%20author">lead author</a>, psychologist <a href="John%20Antonakis">John Antonakis</a>, suggests that leaders should use their intelligence to generate creative <a href="metaphor">metaphor</a>s that will persuade and inspire others. "I think the only way a smart person can signal their intelligence appropriately and still connect with the people," says Antonakis, "is to speak in <a href="charismatic">charismatic</a> ways."
Sociology of science.
Specialization.
<a href="Academic%20specialization">Academic specialization</a> produces great benefits for science and technology by focusing effort on discrete disciplines. But excessively narrow specialization can act as a roadblock to productive collaboration between traditional disciplines.
In 2017, in <a href="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, <a href="James%20Harris%20Simons">James Harris Simons</a>, a noted mathematician and retired founder of one of the world's largest <a href="hedge%20fund">hedge fund</a>s, inaugurated the <a href="Flatiron%20Institute">Flatiron Institute</a>, a nonprofit enterprise whose goal is to apply his hedge fund's analytical strategies to projects dedicated to expanding knowledge and helping humanity. He has established computational divisions for research in astrophysics, biology, and quantum physics, and an interdisciplinary division for <a href="climate%20modelling">climate modelling</a> that interfaces geology, oceanography, atmospheric science, biology, and climatology.
The latter, fourth Flatiron Institute division was inspired by a 2017 presentation to the institute's leadership by <a href="John%20Grotzinger">John Grotzinger</a>, a "bio-geoscientist" from the <a href="California%20Institute%20of%20Technology">California Institute of Technology</a>, who explained the challenges of climate modelling. Grotzinger was a specialist in historical climate change—specifically, what had caused the great <a href="Permian%20extinction">Permian extinction</a>, during which virtually all species died. To properly assess this cataclysm, one had to understand both the rock record and the ocean's composition, but <a href="geologist">geologist</a>s did not interact much with <a href="physical%20oceanography">physical oceanographers</a>. Grotzinger's own best collaboration had resulted from a fortuitous lunch with an oceanographer. Climate modelling was an intrinsically difficult problem made worse by <a href="academia">academia</a>'s structural divisions. "If you had it all under one umbrella... it could result [much sooner] in a major breakthrough." Simons and his team found Grotzinger's presentation compelling, and the Flatiron Institute decided to establish its fourth and final computational division.
Mentoring.
Sociologist <a href="Harriet%20Zuckerman">Harriet Zuckerman</a>, in her 1977 study of natural-science <a href="Nobel%20laureates">Nobel laureates</a> in the United States, was struck by the fact that more than half (48) of the 92 laureates who did their prize-winning research in the U.S. by 1972 had worked either as students, postdoctorates, or junior collaborators under older Nobel laureates. Furthermore, those 48 future laureates had worked under a total of 71 laureate masters.
Social viscosity ensures that not every qualified novice scientist attains access to the most productive centers of scientific thought. Nevertheless, writes Zuckerman, "To some extent, students of promise can choose masters with whom to work and masters can choose among the cohorts of students who present themselves for study. This process of bilateral assortative selection is conspicuously at work among the ultra-elite of science. Actual and prospective members of that elite select their scientist parents and therewith their scientist ancestors just as later they select their scientist progeny and therewith their scientist descendants."
Zuckerman writes: "[T]he lines of elite apprentices to elite masters who had themselves been elite apprentices, and so on indefinitely, often reach far back into the <a href="history%20of%20science">history of science</a>, long before 1900, when [Alfred] Nobel's will inaugurated what now amounts to the International Academy of Sciences. As an example of the many long historical chains of elite masters and apprentices, consider the German-born English laureate <a href="Hans%20Adolf%20Krebs">Hans Krebs</a> (1953), who traces his scientific lineage [...] back through his master, the 1931 laureate <a href="Otto%20Heinrich%20Warburg">Otto Warburg</a>. Warburg had studied with <a href="Hermann%20Emil%20Fischer">Emil Fis[c]her</a> [1852–1919], recipient of a prize in 1902 at the age of 50, three years before it was awarded [in 1905] to "his" teacher, <a href="Adolf%20von%20Baeyer">Adolf von Baeyer</a> [1835–1917], at age 70. This lineage of four Nobel masters and apprentices has its own pre-Nobelian antecedents. Von Baeyer had been the apprentice of <a href="August%20Kekule">F[riedrich] A[ugust] Kekulé</a> [1829–96], whose ideas of <a href="structural%20formulae">structural formulae</a> revolutionized <a href="organic%20chemistry">organic chemistry</a> and who is perhaps best known for the often retold story about his having hit upon the ring structure of <a href="benzene">benzene</a> in a dream (1865). Kekulé himself had been trained by the great <a href="organic%20chemistry">organic chemist</a> <a href="Justus%20von%20Liebig">Justus von Liebig</a> (1803–73), who had studied at the <a href="University%20of%20Paris">Sorbonne</a> with the master <a href="Joseph%20Louis%20Gay-Lussac">J[oseph] L[ouis] Gay-Lussac</a> (1778–1850), himself once apprenticed to <a href="Claude%20Louis%20Berthollet">Claude Louis Berthollet</a> (1748–1822). Among his many institutional and cognitive accomplishments, Berthollet helped found the "<a href="%C3%89cole%20Polytechnique">École Polytechnique</a>", served as science advisor to <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, and, more significant for our purposes here, worked with <a href="Antoine%20Lavoisier">[Antoine] Lavoisier</a> [1743–94] to revise the standard system of <a href="chemical%20nomenclature">chemical nomenclature</a>."
Collaboration.
Sociologist Michael P. Farrell has studied close creative groups and writes: "Most of the fragile insights that laid the foundation of a new vision emerged not when the whole group was together, and not when members worked alone, but when they collaborated and repsonded to one another in pairs." <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20Jacob">François Jacob</a>, who, with <a href="Jacques%20Monod">Jacques Monod</a>, pioneered the study of <a href="gene%20regulation">gene regulation</a>, notes that by the mid-20th century, most research in <a href="molecular%20biology">molecular biology</a> was conducted by twosomes. "Two are better than one for dreaming up theories and constructing models," writes Jacob. "For with two minds working on a problem, ideas fly thicker and faster. They are bounced from partner to partner... And in the process, illusions are sooner nipped in the bud." As of 2018, in the previous 35 years, some half of <a href="Nobel%20Prize%20in%20Physiology%20or%20Medicine">Nobel Prizes in Physiology or Medicine</a> had gone to scientific partnerships. James Somers describes a remarkable partnership between <a href="Google">Google</a>'s top <a href="software%20engineer">software engineer</a>s, <a href="Jeff%20Dean%20%28computer%20scientist%29">Jeff Dean</a> and <a href="Sanjay%20Ghemawat">Sanjay Ghemawat</a>.
Twosome collaborations have also been prominent in creative endeavors outside the <a href="natural%20sciences">natural sciences</a> and <a href="technology">technology</a>; examples are <a href="Monet">Monet</a>'s and <a href="Renoir">Renoir</a>'s 1869 joint creation of <a href="Impressionism">Impressionism</a>, <a href="Pablo%20Picasso">Pablo Picasso</a>'s and <a href="Georges%20Braque">Georges Braque</a>'s six-year collaborative creation of <a href="Cubism">Cubism</a>, and <a href="John%20Lennon">John Lennon</a>'s and <a href="Paul%20McCartney">Paul McCartney</a>'s collaborations on <a href="Beatles">Beatles</a> songs. "Everyone", writes James Somers, "falls into creative ruts, but two people rarely do so at the same time."
The same point was made by <a href="Francis%20Crick">Francis Crick</a>, member of what may be history's most famous scientific duo, Francis Crick and <a href="James%20D.%20Watson">James Watson</a>, who together discovered the structure of the <a href="gene">gene</a>tic material, <a href="DNA">DNA</a>. At the end of a <a href="PBS">PBS</a> television documentary on James Watson, in a video clipping Crick explains to Watson that their collaboration had been crucial to their discovery because, when one of them was wrong, the other would set him straight.
Politics.
Big Science.
What has been dubbed "<a href="Big%20Science">Big Science</a>" emerged from the United States' <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> <a href="Manhattan%20Project">Manhattan Project</a> that produced the world's first <a href="nuclear%20weapons">nuclear weapons</a>; and Big Science has since been associated with <a href="physics">physics</a>, which requires massive <a href="particle%20accelerators">particle accelerators</a>. In <a href="biology">biology</a>, Big Science debuted in 1990 with the <a href="Human%20Genome%20Project">Human Genome Project</a> to sequence human <a href="DNA">DNA</a>. In 2013 <a href="neuroscience">neuroscience</a> became a Big Science domain when the U.S. announced a <a href="BRAIN%20Initiative">BRAIN Initiative</a> and the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> announced a <a href="Human%20Brain%20Project">Human Brain Project</a>. Major new brain-research initiatives were also announced by Israel, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, and China.
Earlier successful Big Science projects had habituated politicians, <a href="mass%20media">mass media</a>, and the public to view Big Science programs with sometimes uncritical favor.
The U.S.'s BRAIN Initiative was inspired by concern about the spread and cost of <a href="mental%20disorders">mental disorders</a> and by excitement about new brain-manipulation technologies such as <a href="optogenetics">optogenetics</a>. After some early false starts, the U.S. <a href="National%20Institute%20of%20Mental%20Health">National Institute of Mental Health</a> let the country's brain scientists define the BRAIN Initiative, and this led to an ambitious interdisciplinary program to develop new technological tools to better monitor, measure, and simulate the brain. Competition in research was ensured by the National Institute of Mental Health's <a href="peer%20review">peer-review process</a>.
In the European Union, the <a href="European%20Commission">European Commission</a>'s Human Brain Project got off to a rockier start because political and economic considerations obscured questions concerning the feasibility of the Project's initial scientific program, based principally on <a href="computer%20modeling">computer modeling</a> of <a href="neural%20circuit">neural circuit</a>s. Four years earlier, in 2009, fearing that the European Union would fall further behind the U.S. in computer and other technologies, the European Union had begun creating a competition for Big Science projects, and the initial program for the Human Brain Project seemed a good fit for a European program that might take a lead in advanced and emerging technologies. Only in 2015, after over 800 European neuroscientists threatened to boycott the European-wide collaboration, were changes introduced into the Human Brain Project, supplanting many of the original political and economic considerations with scientific ones.
As of 2019, the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>'s <a href="Human%20Brain%20Project">Human Brain Project</a> had not lived up to its extravagant promise.
Funding.
Government funding.
<a href="Nathan%20Myhrvold">Nathan Myhrvold</a>, former <a href="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> chief technology officer and founder of <a href="Microsoft%20Research">Microsoft Research</a>, argues that the funding of <a href="basic%20science">basic science</a> cannot be left to the <a href="private%20sector">private sector</a>—that "without government resources, basic science will grind to a halt." He notes that <a href="Albert%20Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>'s <a href="general%20theory%20of%20relativity">general theory of relativity</a>, published in 1915, did not spring full-blown from his brain in a eureka moment; he worked at it for years—finally driven to complete it by a rivalry with mathematician <a href="David%20Hilbert">David Hilbert</a>. The history of almost any iconic scientific discovery or technological invention—the <a href="lightbulb">lightbulb</a>, the <a href="transistor">transistor</a>, <a href="DNA">DNA</a>, even the <a href="Internet">Internet</a>—shows that the famous names credited with the breakthrough "were only a few steps ahead of a pack of competitors." Some writers and elected officials have used this phenomenon of "<a href="list%20of%20multiple%20discoveries">parallel innovation</a>" to argue against public financing of basic research: government, they assert, should leave it to companies to finance the research they need.

"This is most clearly true for the kind of pure research that has delivered... great intellectual benefits but no profits, such as the work that brought us the <a href="Higgs%20boson">Higgs boson</a>, or the understanding that a supermassive <a href="black%20hole">black hole</a> sits at the center of the <a href="Milky%20Way">Milky Way</a>, or the discovery of <a href="methane">methane</a> seas on the surface of <a href="Saturn">Saturn</a>'s moon <a href="Titan%20%28moon%29">Titan</a>. Company research laboratories used to do this kind of work: experimental evidence for the <a href="Big%20Bang">Big Bang</a> was discovered at <a href="AT%26amp%3BT">AT&T</a>'s <a href="Bell%20Labs">Bell Labs</a>, resulting in a <a href="Nobel%20Prize">Nobel Prize</a>.
